segment.source: title: Migrating and upgrading virtual machines
segment.target: title: Migrating and upgrading virtual machines

segment.source: Migrate and upgrade virtual machines
segment.target: Migrate and upgrade virtual machines

segment.source: If you move virtual machines to your Windows 10 host that were originally created with Hyper-V in Windows 8.1 or earlier, you won't be able to use the new virtual machine features until you manually update the virtual machine configuration version.
segment.target: If you move virtual machines to your Windows 10 host that were originally created with Hyper-V in Windows 8.1 or earlier, you won't be able to use the new virtual machine features until you manually update the virtual machine configuration version.

segment.source: To upgrade the configuration version, shut down the virtual machine and then select to Upgrade Virtual Machine Configuration in Hyper-V Manager.
segment.target: To upgrade the configuration version, shut down the virtual machine and then select to Upgrade Virtual Machine Configuration in Hyper-V Manager.

segment.source: You can also open an elevated Windows PowerShell command prompt, and type:
segment.target: You can also open an elevated Windows PowerShell command prompt, and type:

segment.source: TEST UPDATE to see how PowerShell section gets converted.
segment.target: TEST UPDATE to see how PowerShell section gets converted.

segment.source: How do I check the configuration version of the virtual machines running on Hyper-V?
segment.target: How do I check the configuration version of the virtual machines running on Hyper-V?

segment.source: To find the configuration version, open an elevated Windows PowerShell command prompt, and run the following command:
segment.target: To find the configuration version, open an elevated Windows PowerShell command prompt, and run the following command:

segment.source: Get-VM * | Format-Table Name, Version
segment.target: Get-VM * | Format-Table Name, Version

segment.source: The PowerShell command produces the following sample output:
segment.target: The PowerShell command produces the following sample output:

segment.source: What happens if I do not upgrade the configuration version?
segment.target: What happens if I do not upgrade the configuration version?

segment.source: If you have virtual machines that you created with an earlier version of Hyper-V, some features may not work with those virtual machines until you update the VM version.
segment.target: If you have virtual machines that you created with an earlier version of Hyper-V, some features may not work with those virtual machines until you update the VM version.

segment.source: Minimum VM configuration version for new Hyper-V features:
segment.target: Minimum VM configuration version for new Hyper-V features:

segment.source: | Feature Name | Minimum VM version ||
segment.target: | Feature Name | Minimum VM version ||

segment.source: | Hot Add/Remove Memory | 6.0 ||
segment.target: | Hot Add/Remove Memory | 6.0 ||

segment.source: | Hot Add/Remove Network Adapters | 5.0 ||
segment.target: | Hot Add/Remove Network Adapters | 5.0 ||

segment.source: | Secure Boot for Linux VMs | 6.0 ||
segment.target: | Secure Boot for Linux VMs | 6.0 ||

segment.source: | Production Checkpoints | 6.0 ||
segment.target: | Production Checkpoints | 6.0 ||

segment.source: | PowerShell Direct | 6.2 ||
segment.target: | PowerShell Direct | 6.2 ||

segment.source: | Virtual Trusted Platform Module (vTPM) | 6.2 ||
segment.target: | Virtual Trusted Platform Module (vTPM) | 6.2 ||

segment.source: | Virtual Machine Grouping | 6.2 ||
segment.target: | Virtual Machine Grouping | 6.2 ||

segment.source: Virtual Machine Configuration Version
segment.target: Virtual Machine Configuration Version

segment.source: When you move or import a virtual machine to a host running Hyper-V on Windows 10 from host running Windows 8.1, the virtual machine’s configuration file isn't automatically upgraded.
segment.target: When you move or import a virtual machine to a host running Hyper-V on Windows 10 from host running Windows 8.1, the virtual machine’s configuration file isn't automatically upgraded.

segment.source: This allows the virtual machine to be moved back to a host running Windows 8.1.
segment.target: This allows the virtual machine to be moved back to a host running Windows 8.1.

segment.source: You won't have access to new virtual machine features until you manually update the virtual machine configuration version.
segment.target: You won't have access to new virtual machine features until you manually update the virtual machine configuration version.

segment.source: The virtual machine configuration version represents what version of Hyper-V the virtual machine’s configuration, saved state, and snapshot files it's compatible with.
segment.target: The virtual machine configuration version represents what version of Hyper-V the virtual machine’s configuration, saved state, and snapshot files it's compatible with.

segment.source: Virtual machines with configuration version 5 are compatible with Windows 8.1 and can run on both Windows 8.1 and Windows 10.
segment.target: Virtual machines with configuration version 5 are compatible with Windows 8.1 and can run on both Windows 8.1 and Windows 10.

segment.source: Virtual machines with configuration version 6 are compatible with Windows 10 and won't run on Windows 8.1.
segment.target: Virtual machines with configuration version 6 are compatible with Windows 10 and won't run on Windows 8.1.

segment.source: It is not necessary to upgrade all of your virtual machines simultaneously.
segment.target: It is not necessary to upgrade all of your virtual machines simultaneously.

segment.source: You can choose to upgrade specific virtual machines when required.
segment.target: You can choose to upgrade specific virtual machines when required.

segment.source: However, you won't have access to new the virtual machine features until you manually update the configuration version for each virtual machine.
segment.target: However, you won't have access to new the virtual machine features until you manually update the configuration version for each virtual machine.

segment.source: **Important **
segment.target: **Important **

segment.source: • After you upgrade the virtual machine configuration version, you can't move the virtual machine to a host that runs Windows 8.1.
segment.target: • After you upgrade the virtual machine configuration version, you can't move the virtual machine to a host that runs Windows 8.1.

segment.source: • You can't downgrade the virtual machine configuration version from version 6 to version 5.
segment.target: • You can't downgrade the virtual machine configuration version from version 6 to version 5.

segment.source: • You must turn off the virtual machine to upgrade the virtual machine configuration.
segment.target: • You must turn off the virtual machine to upgrade the virtual machine configuration.

segment.source: • After the upgrade, the virtual machine uses the new configuration file format.
segment.target: • After the upgrade, the virtual machine uses the new configuration file format.

segment.source: For more information, see New virtual machine configuration file format.
segment.target: For more information, see New virtual machine configuration file format.

segment.source: What happens when I upgrade the version of a virtual machine?
segment.target: What happens when I upgrade the version of a virtual machine?

segment.source: When you manually upgrade the configuration version of a virtual machine to version 6.x, you'll change the file structure that is used for storing the virtual machines configuration and checkpoint files.
segment.target: When you manually upgrade the configuration version of a virtual machine to version 6.x, you'll change the file structure that is used for storing the virtual machines configuration and checkpoint files.

segment.source: Upgraded virtual machines use a new configuration file format, which is designed to increase the efficiency of reading and writing virtual machine configuration data.
segment.target: Upgraded virtual machines use a new configuration file format, which is designed to increase the efficiency of reading and writing virtual machine configuration data.

segment.source: The upgrade also reduces the potential for data corruption in the event of a storage failure.
segment.target: The upgrade also reduces the potential for data corruption in the event of a storage failure.

segment.source: The following table lists the binary file locations and extension information for an upgraded virtual machine.
segment.target: The following table lists the binary file locations and extension information for an upgraded virtual machine.

segment.source: |Virtual machine configuration and checkpoint files (version 6.x)|Description||
segment.target: |Virtual machine configuration and checkpoint files (version 6.x)|Description||

segment.source: |Virtual machine configuration | Configuration information is stored in a binary file format that uses the .vmcx extension.
segment.target: |Virtual machine configuration | Configuration information is stored in a binary file format that uses the .vmcx extension.

segment.source: |Virtual machine Runtime State | Runtime state data is stored in a binary file format that uses the .vmrs extension.
segment.target: |Virtual machine Runtime State | Runtime state data is stored in a binary file format that uses the .vmrs extension.

segment.source: |Virtual machine virtual hard disk|The virtual hard disk files for the virtual machine.
segment.target: |Virtual machine virtual hard disk|The virtual hard disk files for the virtual machine.

segment.source: They use .vhd or .vhdx file extensions.
segment.target: They use .vhd or .vhdx file extensions.

segment.source: |Automatic virtual hard disk files| The differencing disk files used for virtual machine checkpoints.
segment.target: |Automatic virtual hard disk files| The differencing disk files used for virtual machine checkpoints.

segment.source: They use the .avhdx file extensions.
segment.target: They use the .avhdx file extensions.

segment.source: |Checkpoint Files |Checkpoints are stored in multiple checkpoint files.
segment.target: |Checkpoint Files |Checkpoints are stored in multiple checkpoint files.

segment.source: Each checkpoint creates a configuration file and runtime state file.
segment.target: Each checkpoint creates a configuration file and runtime state file.

segment.source: Checkpoint files use the .vmrs and .vmcx file extensions.
segment.target: Checkpoint files use the .vmrs and .vmcx file extensions.

segment.source: These new file formats are also used for production checkpoints and standard checkpoints.
segment.target: These new file formats are also used for production checkpoints and standard checkpoints.

segment.source: After you upgrade the virtual machine configuration version to version 6.x, it is not possible to downgrade from version 6.x to version 5.
segment.target: After you upgrade the virtual machine configuration version to version 6.x, it is not possible to downgrade from version 6.x to version 5.

segment.source: The virtual machine must be turned off to upgrade the virtual machine configuration.
segment.target: The virtual machine must be turned off to upgrade the virtual machine configuration.

segment.source: The following table lists the default file locations for new or upgraded virtual machines.
segment.target: The following table lists the default file locations for new or upgraded virtual machines.

segment.source: | Virtual Machine Files (Version 6.x) | Description ||
segment.target: | Virtual Machine Files (Version 6.x) | Description ||

segment.source: |Virtual machine configuration file| C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Virtual Machines ||
segment.target: |Virtual machine configuration file| C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Virtual Machines ||

segment.source: |Virtual machine runtime state file| C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Virtual Machines ||
segment.target: |Virtual machine runtime state file| C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Hyper-V\Virtual Machines ||

segment.source: |Checkpoint Files (.vmrs, .vmcx)| C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Snapshots ||
segment.target: |Checkpoint Files (.vmrs, .vmcx)| C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Snapshots ||

segment.source: |Virtual hard disk file (.vhd/.vhdx)| C:\Users\Public\Documents\Hyper-V\Virtual Hard Disks ||
segment.target: |Virtual hard disk file (.vhd/.vhdx)| C:\Users\Public\Documents\Hyper-V\Virtual Hard Disks ||

segment.source: |Automatic virtual hard disk files (.avhdx)| C:\Users\Public\Documents\Hyper-V\Virtual Hard Disks ||
segment.target: |Automatic virtual hard disk files (.avhdx)| C:\Users\Public\Documents\Hyper-V\Virtual Hard Disks ||
